newsitem.title: FRANCE: Snecma reaffirms profit goal for 1997.
newsitem.headline: Snecma reaffirms profit goal for 1997.

text.p: French aerospace group Snecma expects to return to profit in 1997, with annual turnover forecast up 20 percent from 1996, chairman Jean Paul Bechat said on Monday.

"Turnover for 1997 will be 20 percent higher, the net attributable result will be positive," he told journalists at the company's New Year greetings. Sales this year could be between 20-22 billion francs ($4.1 billion), he said. He told newspaper Les Echos in September the Snecma group was approaching breakeven but the parent company itself was still in loss in 1996.
The 1996 net attributable loss was "below 500 million," while sales rose four percent, above 18 billion francs, he said.
Snecma made a 1995 loss of 1.24 billion francs.
All the Snecma group companies, apart from the parent aero-engine maker Snecma SA, are breaking even or proftable, Bechat said.

The losses at Snecma SA were due to a sharp fall since 1991 in sales of the CFM56 civil engines, which it makes in partnership with General Electric of the United States. The CFM International joint venture sells the engine on Boeing and Airbus Industrie jets.
Snecma SA sales account for about half the group's turnover, which fell to 18 billion francs in 1995 from 24 billion in 1991.
But 1997 would see a big recovery in civilian orders, which makes up 73.14 percent of group sales, compared to 28.6 percent in the military area.
Snecma makes engines for the Dassault Aviation Mirage and Rafale combat jets which have been hit by cuts in defence spending.

The Snecma group includes rocket engine maker Societe Europeenne de Propulsion (SEP), undercarriage manufacturer Messier-Dowty, a joint venture with TI Group, brakes company Messier-Bugatti, engine nacelle firm Hispano-Suiza and maintenance firms Techspace Aero and Sochata.
